results.notes: These were growing in two separate locations along F.E. Abernathy Lanana Creek Trail, approximately 300-400 meters apart, but separate environments. One was in a low area that had been flood out a couple times earlier this year. The other was upland of it, in an area composed of heavy wood rot from a couple of broken hardwood snags, possibly Quercus. There were also Magnolia trees present in the area, as well as others. Growing saprobic on decaying hardwood branches. Reddish/maroon pileus, especially near the margins, lightening in color towards the center. Morphology and growth similar to P. arcularius, but then I turned them over to show decurrent gills. These did vary within even branches of color, size, and stipe thickness. No reaction to KOH.
results.location_name: F.E. Abernathy Lanana Creek Trail, Nacogdoches, Texas, USA

results.notes: Growing on the underside of a fallen branch in a predominately Magnolia wood line. Very purple in color. Nearly Indigo. Resupinate growth. I put the branch back, but upside down. When I came back the next day, the colors had seriously faded.
results.location_name: Pecan Acres Park, Nacogdoches, Texas, USA

results.notes:
These images are taken over about 4 month time frame.

Growing on a very decayed hardwood snag. Upland of Lanana Creek in Nacogdoches. Elevation is roughly 300’ above sea level. This area is moist soil, but not bottomland. Growth of the specimens appeared to slow/stop in the winter. Summer growth has been visible over the late winter early spring.

Cap – brown in color. Cracked, and appears to be nearly separate from margin. Distinct color variation between brown pileus and very white margin/hymenium.

Margin – White, bruising brown/dark when rubbed. Nearly separate from pileus.

Pore surface – White bruising brown/dark when touched. Small pore surface. I don’t want to disturb these growths, but plan on taking a sample soon for phylogenetic testing. I will update photos of pores and cross section then.

New growth begins as all white amorphous shape, and will develop over time to the dark brown/near black pileus. Will go from white to rusty/orangish color/ to brown.
results.location_name: F.E. Abernathy Lanana Creek Trail, Nacogdoches, Texas, USA

results.notes: Growing roseate on decaying wood, often very decayed wood. Growing gregariously after rainstorm. Body sizes range from 2-3cm in length to 5-10cm in length. Various width of roseate head. Observed conidia distribution when handled. Observed growing with fruiting bodies of Xylaria cubensis.
results.location_name: F.E. Abernathy Lanana Creek Trail, Nacogdoches, Texas, USA

results.notes:
Following a thunder storm, I was walking Pecan Acres park and looking at fallen branches for lichen and mushrooms. There is one Pecan tree on the Western Edge of the park that is rather stressed. It is debarking and a strong wind will usually bring branches down. This branch was anywhere between 40-70 feet in the air.

Basidiocarps are small. None more than 10mm in length, with the majority probably between 3-6mm.

When I rehydrated them they were possibly 5mm in width.

They were very black and appeared translucent when wet. Growing gregariously over the branch.

They are not attached directly to the branch, so it makes me wonder about the R. applicatus reference I received.

Pileus appeared to be attached to stipe at the center, with hymenium facing downwards.

Longitudinal striations on the pileus, with the gills actually appearing to come from the inside of the stipe.
results.location_name: Pecan Acres Park, Nacogdoches, Texas, USA

results.notes: Smith & Hesler list perplexus at 1-3cm. The examples shown here follow closely Smith & Hesler description with the exception that these perplexus examples consistently show sizes bigger than the original description by Smith & Hesler. Commonly these are over 5cm. The habitat for these shown here is also different. Whereas Smith & Hesler suggest perplexus grows under “aspen and beech on thin sandy soil”, these are under deep shade of mixed conifer forest. Western Red Cedar, Doug Fir, Alder and Maple.
results.location_name: Little Skookum Inlet, Mason Co., Washington, USA

results.notes:
Lichenicolous fungus:
While analyzing some material from past filed trip I saw this example of a lichenicolous fungus growing on a Pertusaria sp. (P. heterochroa I think). It as a somewhat strange grow form, since it appears to be at anamorphic state: the brown/black ascoma are immersed in the apothecia of the host and the fruits, which I’m interpreting as conidia, are brown and 1-septate with average dimensions of Me = 6.2 × 2.9 µm ; Qe = 2.2 (N=20) and aredeveloping at the top of some septate hyphae (conidiophores?) having a radial distribution. I have no idea how to classify it.

results.notes: Growing in duff under a black cherry. Oaks, beech and sugar maple further away. results.notes:
This specimen was the only one salvageable. I dug it out yesterday evening and left it horizontal on the ground in the sun. So it shrank a bit.
Cap is 9.2 X 14.2cm Ø, wavy concave, oval, not a bit viscid, not at all striated at edge, with a very thin patch of remnant veil tissue. Color tan. Remnant veil tissue present in center. Flesh is quite firm and nearly white.
This was found in a small grassland just below an area specifically maintained for early seral sand hill species by regular burning and removal of invading brush.

Cohorts within 40 feet
Elymus glaucus Bromus carinatus
Stipa lepida
Diplacus aurantiacus Ceanothus papillosus
Eriodictyon californicum Quercus parvula shrevei
Acmispon americanus Acmispon glaber
Navarretia atractyloides Trifolium microdon
Pterostegia drymarioides Filago californica
Camissonia contorta Calandrinia ciliata
Crassula connata Lupinus bicolor
Epilobium minutum Cryptantha micromeres
Uropappus lindleyi Pseudognaphalium californicum
Difficult to cut without breaking.
Gills are adnexed to free (in age), occasionally alternate, white to cream, with small brown flecks along the edges.
Stipe also oval in cross section 3.5-3.7cm Ø X 11cm long, white with finely textured scales, flaring at the top, solid, dry, no stain, breaks clean. No odor. Decaying in center.
Stipe length was measured from the gills to the end of the volva.
Volva is well defined, sac-like for the top 1-1.5cm with no annulus or veil tissue observed on any specimen.
Growing in sand about 30 feet from the nearest tree. Grass cover primarily Elymus glaucus.

results.notes:
Strobilurus tenacellus (Pers.) Singer Physalacriaceae, Agaricales (Стробилюрус черенковый)
Tiny yellowish-brown mushroom with elastic narrow long brownish stalk
Cap: 0.5-2 cm wide convex when young then wide convex with tiny gentle knob up to almost flat with slightly sunken center and thin margin; smooth, sometimes radial lined; color light yellowish-brown minor brown
Flesh is very thin and whitish or brownish-white.
Gills: almost free or attached with pinching out, moderately broad minor narrow, rather close and almost distant with short and very short additional gills, whitish, somewhat light yellowish- or brownish-white.
Stalk: 3.5-6 cm long, 1.2-2.0mm thick, light yellowish-brown, some elastic and fibrous (fine velvety or hairy outer tube). Stalk base often looks as a tree root or long inner tube? sometimes twice longer than outer tube.
Edibility: no accurate data for this location; probably edible, because the odor is weak and pleasant.
Habitat: rare kind; scattered on soil in pine-tree forest with some birches and aspen.
April – June.

results.notes:
Code: Bot_944/2016_DSC1359

Habitat: mixed wood, Fagus sylvatica and Picea abies dominant, calcareous, alluvial ground, almost flat terrain, probably locally acid ground (Vaccinium myrtillus abundant), in shade; partly protected from direct rain by tree canopies, average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 3-5 deg C, elevation 1.000 m (3.280 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: stump, roots and small twigs of Picea abies in the last stage of disintegration.

Place: Zadnja Trenta valley, ‘Zapodn’ place, right side of (dry) bed of river Soča, between a small dam and the first ravine downstream of it, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comments: Mycena stipata is relatively recently defined (1987). Two varieties (some authors consider them species) are known, which differ only microscopically: Mycena stipata var. stipata and Mycena stipata var. silvae-nigrae. The last one is typically a spring taxon, but its spores are according to Krieglsteiner (2001) significantly larger that what I measured (10-15/7-10 microns). Mycena stipata var. stipata grows mainly in autumn but also appears in spring. Spores fit well to this taxon.

Growing in groups, a few together and also single; about 20 fruit bodies all together in an area of about 0.6 × 0.3 m; pilei diameter 16 – 26 mm, height 10-16 mm; stipe 2.5 – 3.5 mm diameter and 3 – 5 cm tall, hollow, fragile, smooth, with white mycelium at the base; taste rather strong, unpleasant; smell mild, mushroomy, on chemicals, a kind of nitrous; SP abundant, whitish-beige, oac900; pilei cuticle peels off in long narrow bands up to one half or more of pilei diameter. No microscopic study of hyphae and basidia has been done; hence the determination is not certain.

Nikon D700/Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8
results.location_name: Zadnja Trenta Valley, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia

results.notes:
Gyromitra Fr., Helvellaceae, Pezizales (вероятно, Дисцина щитовидная)
Stalkless yellow-brown plate-shaped or ear-shaped fragile mushroom

Cup: 4-8cm wide plate-shaped up to ear-shaped with smooth surface, wrinkled and fragile; upper surface yellow-brown or brownish-yellow, minor light reddish-brown, lower (bottom) surface brownish-white or yellowish-white up to light-brown. Flesh is whitish and brittle.
Stalk: stalk is absent or it is stalk-like cup bottom curve.
It grows on sandy soil with pine-tree needles or aspen leaves in pine-tree forest with some aspen and birches.
Edibility: published that edible after short boiling.
Season: April-May

results.notes:
Growing on bark.
I was not able to reach a name for this specimen. The grow form clearly indicates Opegrapha. Its spores are 3-spetate with the following dimensions:
(12.1) 12.8 – 16.5 (17.3) × (3.4) 3.8 – 4.7 (4.9) µm
Q = (2.8) 3.1 – 3.66 (3.7) ; N = 17
Me = 14.3 × 4.3 µm ; Qe = 3.3 .
Looking to the British Flora the species with more similar features are O. herbarum and O. ochrocheila. However, from O. herbarum it differs in having smaller and thinner spores, though it has halonate spores a distinguish feature of that species among those with the same spore septation, and the hymenium reacts I+ blue and not I+ red. From O. ochrocheila it differs in the halonate spores and the lacking of an orange/red pigment in the exciple and epihymenium.

results.notes:
Gillis Canyon Road in eastern San Luis Obispo County. Collected accidentally with Lecanora saligna group (observation 236876) from old ranch fence boards.

Thallus greenish brown, areolate, scurfy or esorediate accounting for a fine bumpy texture, irregularly continuous to rimose, K-, C-, KC-. Medulla white. Apothecia black, lecideine, becoming convex and losing raised margin in age. Epihymenium brown. Hymenium hyaline. Paraphyses with reddish brown tips. Pycnidia not found. Asci with 8 spores each. Spores brown, ellipsoid (narrowly when squished out of ascus), sometimes slightly curved like a bean, without ornamentation, 1-septate, somewhat constricted at septa.
Spore Measurements:
12.0×6.0µm
14.6×6.0µm
13.4×6.0µm
13.8×6.6µm
13.1×5.9µm

results.notes:
-This bolete forms part of a complex relationship between mealybugs (Pseudococcus comstocki), fire ants (Solenopsis saevissima var. moelleri) and citrus trees. The mealybugs are ferried around by the ants, who farm them for their honeydew. The females are either brought into the ant nest or wander in on their own, where they oviposit onto the roots. There the fungus encases the young mealybugs in a mycelial sheath or ‘cripta’, from which fruiting bodies eventually emerge. The more P. tropicus fruiting at and around the base of the citrus tree, the more significant the damage.-

UPDATE: 4-25-16 Thanks to Dr. Roy Halling (royh) for supplying some much needed literature to clarify (confuse?) the identity of our fungus. P. tomentosus appears to be a more likely ID than P. tropicus, but P. portentosus is a taxonomic conundrum unto itself. To the extent that it is a single, well-defined species (not likely), it and P. tropicus, have some interesting ecological overlap. See comments for details.

All tissues reddening in KOH. First-observed fruiting bodies (images 1-10) exhibited only subtle blueing. Those found two days later from the same site (images 11-14), which were considerably older and more bug-eaten, exhibited both more bluing and more red in the pileus and stem context tissues without the presence of KOH. They were also found as we were leaving when all the camera gear was packed, hence the lower quality cell phone shots.

results.notes:
This is a blight of misc. tree species in the Neotropics. It can cover entire trees from trunk to tip. turning them ghost white. It forms rounded knobs on hanging rhizomorphs which give rise to conidia, and may be an anamorph of Brunneocorticium; a crust in Marasmiaceae. The rhizomorphs are sometimes used as nest building material by neighboring birds.

This fungus was as unknown to me as it was ubiquitous in Neotropical forests until Dr. Jean Lodge recognized it in photos shown to her by suse. See http://www.apsnet.org/... for more information.

results.notes:
I returned to the place of observation 202652 and the scene was repeated. In two of the granite blocks I found a large number of specimens with the same characteristics of that observation. One of the specimens, the presented at the last picture taken on site, shows the most developed apothecia that are similar to some species of Rinodina I have ever encountered, particularly R. atrocinerea and R. beccariana.
While I do not have the means to collect rock samples in this case they will not serve much, since the rock is compact and has no cracks. Thus, as the other time, I limited myself to collect a sample by scraping with the tip of the knife, collecting the fragments on paper.
What I got was such a fine powder that microscopy limited myself to put two or three grains on a slide. The result was what presented in the attached photographs.
These are instructive and show that my previous ideas about this lichen were correct. The hymenium and spores are clearly a species of the genus Rinodina and the spores are Pachysporaria-type. Taking into account the analysis of the species with these spores made in the comments of observation 204088 and the chemistry (C+ & KC+ orange/red, K+ yellow, spot tests carried out on the observation cited above), I think we are in the presence of specimens of species R. atrocinerea, which I have already found this year elsewhere (see observation 236227).

P.S.: Just now I consulted the webpage of AFL and saw the photos of “Rinodina aspersa subsp. atrocinerea” and the 2nd photo (magnification of the 1st?) show very similar young apothecia emerging from the areolas; Link: http://www.afl-lichenologie.fr/...

results.notes:
This observation is very much related with observation 110992. Reading the comments there, instead of “collect the whole tree” and in this way “kill the goose that lays the golden eggs” I decided to wait and observe the specimens from time to time. During more than three years very few happened. Recently I noticed that some apothecia were best visible, because some black dots could better seen (though it is difficult with the naked eye, due to size) due to degradation of the thallus. Finally I decide to get a sample and analyze it.
Meanwhile, in Sep. 2014 Jason post observation 179005 with a specimen named Arthonia susa that I found very similar to my specimens (compare the photos). There we also discussed a bit of the taxonomy: while N.A. people place arthoniod specimens in the genus Arthonia, European people call them Arthothelium, at least the British Flora does but refers that this genus in not universally accepted.
From the microscopy we can see that the above suppositions were right. From the sections we can see the arthonioid characteristic apothecia and, moreover, the spores are muriform, though a bit smaller than those found by Jason in observation 179005; I got the following dimensions:
(20.3) 22.1 – 26.1 (26.5) × (8) 8.8 – 11.57 (11.6) µm
Q = (2.2) 2.25 – 2.6 (2.7) ; N = 10
Me = 23.7 × 10 µm ; Qe = 2.4 .
Taking into account that the spores have not an individed enlarged upper cell and (at least some) of the spores has more than one longitudinal septa, according to the Bristish Flora there are to possibilities: either Arthotellium orbiliforum, if a photobiont is absent, or A. ruanum, if the photobiont is Trentepohilia. Since these specimens have an algae layer in apothecia, I think that more likely they belong to Arthotellium ruanum, although I’m not completely sure that the alga is a Trentepohlia. I must also refer that some parts of its description apply as a glove to these specimens; quoting: " Apothecia … irregularly rounded to blunty stellate, often desintegrating in places and regenerating to give the appearance of a crowded swarm of punctiform apothecia, black, not pruinose (but often long remaining covered by bark cells) …".
This for me is like: Mission accomplished!

results.notes:
This must be a very unusual species growing on a block of granite . As peculiar features it presents spores of “Mischoblastia-type”, which according to the British Flora are present in a few number of species: R. fimbriata, R. oxydata and R. teichophila. The spores are bigger than in most of the Rinodina spp. with the following dimensions:
(19.8) 20.7 – 27.6 (28.5) × (9.8) 11.2 – 14.4 (15.2) µm
Q = (1.7) 1.8 – 2.1 (2.3) ; N = 43
Me = 24.3 × 12.6 µm ; Qe = 1.9 .
R. oxydata can be ruled out, because it has a different appearance, in general, and the spores are a bit smaller and narrower. For the remaining species, R. teichophila has not only spores of “Mischoblastia-type” but spores said to be of “Mischoblastia- to Pachysporaria-type”; Spores of “Pachysporaria-type” I have encountered in R. atrocinerea and R. beccariana and there are no spores here of this type. If some exist not of “Mischoblastia-type”, then the closest are “Dirinaria-type” (see the photo of the spore where these types are displayed for convenience). However, this species cannot be ruled out.
The most promissing seems to be R. fimbriata. Its description in the British Flora fits quite well except that it has no lichen substances. Here I faced the recurrent problem for the specimens living in hard rock (as this one) for which a sample is only possible collecting some apothecia (if they are big enough, which is not the case as can be seen in the photo, where the dimensions of the apothecia are less than 1 mm in diameter) or scratching the rock with the knife (method used here). In this case a small piece of the thallus came with the sample and it seems that some lichen subtances should be present: K+ pale yellow and KC+ yellow, though this is not certain, I can be wrong and is not possible to recheck.
Finally, once and again the missing checklist of lichens of Portugal could be useful. However, the present checklist is common with that of Spain and it is not possible to know the origin of the names there mentioned. Only, that all the species referred above are in that checklist.
Summarizing, I will go for R. fimbriata, but it can also be R. teichophila.

results.notes:
These were growing in a fairly open area where the 2 year old Rim Fire had occurred.
The cap on the larger one was 3 cm high and the stipe was 5.5 cm long.
The cap was attached to the stem with a short flat ridge.
The hollow stem was thinly ridged and very mealy.
Spores were ~ 22.0-28.0 X 14.0-17.9 microns, mostly ellipsoid(Qavg = 1.57), and contents uniform.
Paraphyses were cylindrical and ~ 12-13 microns wide.
Overall the fruitbodies were rather delicate.
The spores look too small for M. brunnea and they look somewhat like Kuo’s(Darvin’s) Morchella Mel-8 with darker ridges.

results.notes:
I apologize if this is a waste of anyone’s time, but I’m stuck and VERY curious.

I found this and I have NO idea not what fungi it is, but whether it’s a fungi at all! I think it’s not a fungi, but then what else could it be? I’m hoping the people here as nature lovers who’ve spent lots of time outdoors might recognize whatever this is. It almost looks like an egg laid in gelatinous mucous to keep it moist which would make me guess it’s something from an amphibian.

I really wish I had removed it or broke it open.
